bestBHT.bht: The righteousness of the one who generously scatters resources to the poor proves goodness and abides forever. This generous man gives without anxious thought, like a sower scattering seed with a full and open hand. His acts of beneficence manifest his righteousness before God and man, leaving a lasting impact. Just as the seed sown brings forth fruit and increase, his generous gifts to the needy are not lost but renewed by God. Thus, his righteousness remains unexhausted, with God continually renewing his store.

Henry Alford: Clearly in the only one warranted by the context—that of ‘goodness proved by beneficence,’
To build any inference from the text inconsistent with the great truths respecting righteousness ever insisted on by St. Paul...is a manifest perversion.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: As it is written—realizing the highly blessed character portrayed."
dispersed—as seed sown with full and open hand, without anxious thought in what direction each grain may fall.
his righteousness—Here 'beneficence': the evidence of his being righteous before God and man.
Albert Barnes: On such a man a blessing is pronounced... one of the blessings will be that he shall be prospered."
Perhaps Paul quoted this... where a passage was familiar. He quotes only a part of the passage, meaning that the whole passage confirms the point under consideration."
His righteousness - His deeds of beneficence. Remaineth - In its fruits and consequences; that is, either in its effects on others, or on himself.
Marvin Vincent: He hath dispersed abroad [εσκορπισεν] . As in sowing, ver. 6. Psalms 112:9. Almost literally after the Hebrew and Septuagint.
John Calvin: He will not be wanting in doing good, but as water flows forth incessantly from a perennial fountain, so the gushing forth of his liberality will be unceasing.
Paul has an eye to this — that we be not weary in well doing.
It is an easy matter for God to bless us with plenty, so that we may exercise our bounty freely, deliberately, and impartially.
Philip Schaff: He hath scattered abroad 'a generous word' (says Bengel), 'with a full hand, not anxiously thinking about the single grains;'" (2 Corinthians 9:9).
He hath given to the poor: his righteousness (in dispersing abroad of his means) abideth for ever enabling him always to manifest by his gifts what he is" (2 Corinthians 9:9).
That this is the sense of 'righteousness abiding' here, is evident from 2 Corinthians 9:10" (2 Corinthians 9:9).
Archibald T. Robertson: He hath scattered abroad (εσκορπισεν). It is like sowing seed.
To the poor (τοις πενησιν). Only N.T. instance and to be distinguished from πτωχος, beggar, abjectly poor.
Old word from πεναμα, to work for one's living. Latin penuria and Greek πειναω, to be hungry, are kin to it.
John Gill: He hath dispersed his riches, his substance, as the Chaldee paraphrase adds by way of explanation; not in a profuse extravagant manner, but with wisdom and prudence, and yet largely and liberally, according to his ability.
Just as the sower scatters his seed here, and there, and in every place, with an open and wide hand, to the good man distributes to all in necessity, and makes them all partakers of his bounty.
What such a man bestows in charity on the poor shall not be lost, but shall be like the seed cast into the earth, shall spring up again, and bring forth fruit with increase.
John Wesley: He hath scattered abroad — (A generous word.) With a full hand, without any anxious thought which way each grain falls.
His righteousness — His beneficence, with the blessed effects of it.
Remaineth for ever — Unexhausted, God still renewing his store. Psalm 112:9

bhtAttempts.bht: The verse speaks of the righteousness of the man who scatters his resources generously to the poor and needy. This righteousness, understood as goodness proven by beneficence, remains forever, a blessed character that is portrayed. Just as a sower scatters seed without worrying where each grain falls, this benevolent man gives abundantly without anxiety. His righteousness is evident in his acts of beneficence, enabling him to manifest what he is and leaving a lasting impact. It is like sowing seed, with the assurance that it will bring forth fruit and increase, not lost but renewed by God.

The righteousness of the one who generously scatters resources to the poor is portrayed as goodness proven by beneficence, which remains forever. This generous man gives without anxiously considering where each grain falls, resembling a sower scattering seed. His acts of beneficence manifest his righteousness and have a lasting impact. Like sowing seed, his generosity will bring forth fruit and increase, not lost but renewed by God. He will continue to do good, as his liberality flows unceasingly like water from a perennial fountain.

The righteousness of the one who generously disperses resources to the poor is a manifestation of goodness proven by beneficence. This righteousness remains forever, continuously renewing its store like a perennial fountain. Just as a sower scatters seed without anxious consideration, this generous man gives abundantly, without worrying about where each grain falls. His acts of beneficence leave a lasting impact, allowing him to manifest the blessed character portrayed and bringing forth fruit and increase, not lost but renewed by God.

The righteousness of the one who generously scatters resources to the poor proves goodness and abides forever. This generous man gives without anxious thought, like a sower scattering seed with a full and open hand. His acts of beneficence manifest his righteousness before God and man, leaving a lasting impact. Just as the seed sown brings forth fruit and increase, his generous gifts to the needy are not lost but renewed by God. Thus, his righteousness remains unexhausted, with God continually renewing his store.

The righteousness of the one who generously scatters resources to the poor remains forever. This righteousness, understood as goodness proven by beneficence, leaves a lasting impact. Just as a sower scatters seed without anxious thought, this generous man gives abundantly, without worrying about where each grain falls. His acts of beneficence manifest his righteousness, allowing him to continually renew his store, like a perennial fountain. His benevolence is like sowing seed, bringing forth fruit and increase, not lost but renewed by God.
